sn10.5:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn10.5:1.2: Now at that time a certain lay woman had a son named Sānu who had been possessed by a native spirit.
sn10.5:1.3: And as that lay woman wept, on that occasion she recited these verses:
sn10.5:2.1: “I have heard this from the perfected ones.
sn10.5:2.2: The native spirits will not mess with anyone
sn10.5:3.2: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,
sn10.5:3.3: and the eighth day of the fortnight,
sn10.5:3.4: as well as on the fortnight of special displays.
sn10.5:4.1: “What you heard from the perfected ones is right.
sn10.5:4.2: The native spirits will not mess with anyone
sn10.5:5.2: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,
sn10.5:5.3: and the eighth day of the fortnight,
sn10.5:5.4: as well as on the fortnight of special displays.
sn10.5:6.1: When Sānu regains consciousness tell him
sn10.5:6.2: this saying of the native spirits:
sn10.5:7.1: If you should do a bad deed,
sn10.5:7.3: you won’t be freed from suffering,
sn10.5:7.4: though you fly away and flee.”
sn10.5:8.2: or for one who’s alive but has disappeared.
sn10.5:8.3: I’m alive and you can see me,
sn10.5:8.4: so mum, why do you weep for me?”
sn10.5:9.2: or for one who’s alive but has disappeared.
sn10.5:9.3: But someone who has given up sensual pleasures
sn10.5:9.4: only to come back here again:
sn10.5:9.5: they cry for them as well,
sn10.5:9.6: for though still alive they’re really dead.
sn10.5:10.1: My dear, you’ve been rescued from hot coals,
sn10.5:10.2: and you want to plunge right back in them!
sn10.5:10.3: My dear, you’ve been rescued from the abyss,
sn10.5:10.4: and you want to plunge right back there!
sn10.5:11.1: Keep pushing forward, it’s what’s best for you!
sn10.5:11.2: Who have I got to complain to?
sn10.5:11.3: When your things have been saved from a fire,
sn10.5:11.4: would you want them to be burnt again?”
